"Venezuela has about $2.5 billion cash available for debt payments, the two other sources said, from its total $14.56 billion of international reserves. Of about $10 billion debt due throughout 2016, more than $4 billion, mainly of state oil company PDVSA, must be paid in October and November. Credit default swaps show traders see a more than 70 percent chance of default in the next year.
. . . 
"Underlining the challenge, PDVSA is talking with international banks about a debt refinancing, while the central bank is negotiating a gold swap with Deutsche Bank to monetize reserves and sent 34 tonnes to Switzerland in January, according to customs there. "Venezuela hopes China may provide a financial lifeline for later in the year, although a source in the Maduro government said Beijing has cross-default provisions in its loans to Caracas, indicating it could turn the screw if repayment problems arise. "If Venezuela's crude stays around $25 per barrel, it faces a total $32 billion financing gap for debt and imports this year, according to Bank of America. "In the run-up to Friday's payment, Venezuela's reserves received a $1.8 billion boost from off-budget funds totaling $4 billion and mainly financed by China, one source close to the government economic team said. "Also, state bodies hold about 35 percent of debt maturing on Friday. The government did not immediately confirm the cash was set aside for Friday's payment, but markets have factored that in. "Later in the year, however, "there's a close to 100 percent probability there will be a restructuring," said Ruggero de Rossi, a portfolio manager for Federated Investors.

Just announced that Venezuela moved about 10% of its gold reserves from Caracas to Switzerland in January. Once certified, that's over US $1 billion that they can use for either imports or debt repayment. Rumor is they've been in touch with several financial orgs including Deutsche Bank to either leverage or swap the gold. The fact they made this very bold move with their gold reserves, on top of their recent replacement of economic ministers and limited economic measures, point to the fact they are on target to pay in February. Separately, the bond market is allowing people to buy the bonds due this month at about 95 cents on the dollar. That is an amazing rate of return on less than two weeks, but also implies that the markets still have some level of uncertainty. With this gold announcement, I've moved my estimate down from 29 to 14 here. They are likely to pay the pdvsa debt with the dollars they have gained in the gold switch. I wouldn't be shocked if they asked for 30 day grace period on their sovereign bonds, but appear more willing to pay than not. Things could still go wrong, but they are in a better position for the February payment today than they appeared a month ago. They're still better than 70% likely to be in default after the October/November payments.
Moving odds back down for passage of time, replacement of pro-default Economy Minister Salas

It appears highly likely that PDVSA will be able to make their $2b+ debt payment on Feb 26.  Once they make that payment, there will be very little chance that they will default before their next debt payment in FQ3.  If they had another major payment due the first week of March, the risk may be higher, but they have no incentive to default until the last possible moment.

Amid what he called an economic war waged against the Bolivarian Revolution, which he says has lead to an unprecedented economic crisis, Pres. Nicolas Maduro announced a hike in the price of gasoline, something that hasn't happened since 1997.  The new price for the 95 octane gasoline is the equivalent to .11 cents of dollar, compared to the previous price which was about a fifth of a penny per gallon.  91-octane gasoline will increase to 1 bolivar a liter from 7 centavos. Maduro also announced currency changes which will devalue official exchange rate by 37%.   The 6.3 bolivars per US dollar exchange rate for food and medicine will now weaken to 10.  The Sistema Marginal de Divisas which has an exchange rate of some 203 bolivars per dollar, is now going to be converted into a floating rate system.  Many are calling these desperate measures too little, too late to avoid a default in the fourth quarter. But for the purposes of this question, looks like they're safe between now and March.

COMMENT:  The Reuters piece also noted that Maduro has appointed a new economic VP, industrial engineer Miguel Perez, former head of a small and medium-sized businesses association, a man who admires the country's socialist policies but recognizes the need for market reforms. Perez has voiced support for unification of Venezuela's three official exchange rates, an idea  backed by bondholders who believe the corruption-ridden exchange controls are driving the country toward default. But opposition critics were quick to dismiss his designation as improvisation Maduro, who just last month shuffled his Cabinet. Bottomline for me is that the new economic czar is an improvement over the previous man, and serious efforts are being made to re-negotiate loan terms, but all this will only delay the crisis if Maduro doesn't agree to radical restructuring of the nation's economy, starting perhaps with increasing the price of gasoline from something around 1 cent per gallon.
Not before the end of the month.

Pres. Nicolas Maduro just replaced his vice president for the economy, Luis Salas, the college professor who said inflation doesn't exist, after just 5 weeks. In his place, Maduro named Miguel Perez Abad, the former commerce minister.  This is another desperate move from Maduro as the chances of default increase but unless he's willing to be flexible on his ideology, default is certain.  Maduro said he would announce other economic measures today, but he's not expected to raise gasoline prices or to devalue the Bolivar, both measures seen as indicators he is moving to avoid a default. "So is a peaceful political transition possible? Venezuela is on its way to democracy and it is unlikely that Maduro can do more than delay what looks like an inevitable fall from power. The government controls most of the institutions, including the Supreme Court. But while some in the military have benefited from corruption under the current regime, the armed forces are also split into factions and their loyalty is hard to divine.

"The math behind these warnings is stark, as economist Ricardo Hausmann recently outlined in the Financial Times. At current oil prices, Venezuela will earn less than $18 billion from exports this year, while it owes $10 billion in payments on the $120 billion in debt it has racked up. That leaves $8 billion for imports, but even after contracting 20 percent, imports were $37 billion in 2015 — and Venezuela now imports most of its food. Even with a debt default that the markets expect, it’s hard to see where additional hard currency will come from: The country broke relations with the International Monetary Fund almost a decade ago, has no ability to obtain private loans and has nearly exhausted its liquid reserves. It already owes China, its latest benefactor, $50 billion."

First, President Nicolás Maduro’s administration decided to sell off some US$1.5 billion worth of Venezuela’s gold reserves in order to obtain some cash and meet bond obligations which expire in February. As economist and opposition lawmaker José Guerra explained, selling gold can be considered a normal operation, but not now, when Venezuela is in “desperate” circumstances. “We maintain our good reputation with every timely bond payment,” he said, “but at the same time we are left off with less reserves to meet future obligations. Given the country’s economic stagnation, we can expect a rise in the cost of lending.” The Maduro administration loves to disparage capitalism, US imperialism, and international organizations and lenders. But it does whatever it takes — such as ruining the country’s economic future and leaving the population without food — to keep paying foreign bondholders. This can only mean one thing: all the regime’s elite cares about is staying in power.

COMMENT:  I've read that some financial advisors actually think that it would be wise for Venezuela to default now, before it has no options.  I hope Maduro isn't listening to them!  Frankly, I think he is too proud to allow his nation to default.  But do you see the beads of sweat on my forehead?  It is getting very scary to be at 0%! . . .  only 18 days to go.

Oil prices have crashed to new 13 year lows.  Those who think a default this month makes sense, given the hopelessness of making it through the year without a default, may have more ammo. Edit: Rationale explained in an earlier post is that some may think, "why strip the country of all its assets if ultimately it ends of in the same situation anyway?" OTH, paying this tranche off may give corrupt officials more time to plunder what they can into their own accounts. The sharp drop in prices may focus their minds more on that endeavour.

Venezuela is a bit of a black box.  However, my opinion is that they have an overall incentive to maintain availability to external funding, given the current macroeconomic conditions. Maduro's administration has had catastrophic consequences, with unbelievably high inflation rates and basic goods scarcity. As his popularity sinks, he is in the need of external resources, (i.e. international funding). The only real threat to Venezuela's and PDVSA (who have the same credit risk) credit profile is the USD 1.5bn bond maturing on February 26. S&P and Fitch ratings are already CCC, though. This means that, according to them, a default is very likely to happen within the next 6 months, without improved external conditions. Oil prices are expected to keep falling along the year, mainly due to Iranian addition to global supply, this should pose additional pressure to Venezuela's government. Will Venezuela default before the March 1st, 2016? I don't think so. The country has significant gold and cash reserves enough to cover its debt payments, at least for the ones maturing in February. I believe that, if conditions don't improve, they will eventually default, but not in the next 19 days.

Feb 09, 2016 The barely stocked grocery shelves in Venezuela are about to get even barer. With the price of oil, the country’s lifeblood, tumbling to lows not seen in more than a decade, analysts are warning that the embattled government of Nicolás Maduro will struggle to pay its debts, fund its imports and service its foreign bonds this year. Markets have been increasingly pricing in the possibility of a default, with prices for many of its bonds due after this year trading at between 32 cents to 37 cents on the dollar — a level considered distressed. Meanwhile, the cost of insuring Venezuelan government bonds and debt issued by state-owned oil company PDVSA are surging once again. But if forced to choose between default or cutting imports, Francisco Rodríguez, analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lynch, reckons Venezuela’s cash strapped government would choose the latter and take the risk of worsening the country’s shortage of basic goods rather miss a debt repayment. “Absent major corrections to relative prices, scarcity could rise to levels that would make 2015 seem like a time of abundance,” he wrote in a note on Tuesday.....

Venezuela is in desperate straits, both politically and economically. President Maduro has been a weak successor to Chavez, with lukewarm popular support, and his party has maintained control of the legislature after the recent elections only by packing the Supreme Court before new legislators took office, and then using the Court to invalidate the elections of four opposition legislators.  The Venezuelan economic situation is terrible. Venezuela depends on its oil sales for 96% of its hard currency and 40-50% of its budget (http://www.cnbc.com/2016/02/04/venezuela-flirts-with-default-could-be-worse-than-argentina.html ), at a time when oil prices have dropped from over $100 a barrel to around $30. The Venezuelan government has continued high levels of spending on its social programs in spite of the shortfall in revenue.  Venezuelans are suffering food shortages, and queues at food outlets form at 3 o'clock in the morning for an all-day wait for foodstuffs that may no longer be on the shelves when they reach the head of the line, (http://www.economist.com/news/americas/21690098-country-brink-social-explosion-only-negotiated-transition-can?zid=305&ah=417bd5664dc76da5d98af4f7a640fd8a — maybe behind the paywall). Venezuelan statistics are unreliable, but some estimates put inflation this year around 700% or higher. (http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2016-02-07/venezuela-prepares-liquidate-its-remaining-gold-holdings-pay-coming-debt-maturities .)  Zero Hedge also reports that "Venezuela is now literally flying in paper money (using three dozen cargo Boeing 747s)."  Not a problem, says Venezuelan "economic tsar ... Luis Salas, a sociologist who comes from the far-left fringes of chavismo. He regards inflation as a capitalist conspiracy against consumers and denies that the Central Bank helps cause it by printing money to finance the budget deficit." (He apparently missed the Milton Friedman lecture in his economics class. Oh, wait — he didn't do economics.) (http://www.economist.com/news/americas/21688865-president-and-opposition-are-talking-each-other-does-not-mean-they-will-fix?zid=305&ah=417bd5664dc76da5d98af4f7a640fd8a ) The economy is contracting, perhaps 7% last year, impoverishing more Venezuelans.  Venezuela faces a payment on its debt on February 26, and vows it will make the payment. (Wall Street Journal, no link.) It has, however, only $1.5 billion in foreign exchange, and it is taking the desperate step of pledging its gold reserves against its debt. It was doing the same with the Bank for International Settlements, but the BIS stopped making those deals last year, because of the associated risk. If things go south, Venezuela will have to actually pony up the physical gold, which has in itself gotten complicated because Chavez moved all Venezuela's gold from foreign banks where it had been held to Venezuela's central bank, and now counterparties on the gold deals want the gold certified — i.e., is this really gold you're shipping me, or gilded lead bars? (Read the Zero Hedge post.) And for a final twist, the value of gold has been dropping, as we know.  It will be a close-run thing if Venezuela avoids default in February.

I’m reaffirming my 24% number. Adding some context to those coming to this now. Here is the conventional wisdom:
1) Venezuela has “always” made its sovereign bond payments.
2) They have enough money to pay in February and will therefore do so.
3) They will likely default later in 2016 in October or November. The base scenario is that they will pay the $2.1 billion they owe in February (I’ve got it 64% likely that they will pay,  below market rate but still above a coin flip) and default in October or November (chances are better than 80% of a default this year). Why would Venezuela default now instead of later this year (in order to likelihood)?
1) They just don’t have the money. It’s possible that they want to pay but that their bank accounts have run dry. While they have $15 billion reserves on paper, a significant portion of the foreign reserves are in gold, which aren’t liquid and can’t be used for payments. They probably only have $1.5-3 billion in cash and must burn through $1.1 billion in cash per month to pay for food. For those who like math, $1.1 billion for food plus $2.1 billion for debt equals $3.2 billion in payments in February for a government that has at most $3 billion in cash reserves. Yet, nearly everyone (myself included) is working on the assumption they will magically make $200 million appear between now and the end of February to make the payment. Our conventional wisdom rests of the belief that they will pull some financial rabbit out of the hat (again). The fact the numbers don’t add up and we’re all waiting to see this financial magic should push at least a few of you down around the 0% number to hedge at least slightly. Remember, the Maduro economic team is a bunch of amateurs right now. Given the cash squeeze, they could screw this up by simply not having the funds they think they have the moment the bond payment is due. 2) They recognize that they will likely default later this year and choose to default early and use the money for food and other imports. This could be a strategic decision on their part. 3) If there is an ICSID ruling against the country (Venezuela faces about two dozen outstanding cases there worth several billion dollars) and Venezuela chooses not to pay or can’t pay, the country enters instant default. No rulings are expected until Quarter 2 of this year, so this is an unlikely scenario for the next month but is still a possibility. 4) If some bond holders find a legal mechanism to accelerate their payments. Should it happen? No. But some of these bond holders are sharks that smell blood and are willing to use any technicality they can. Final note: The $1.5 billion sovereign bond payment due in late February has a 30 day grace period (and GJ may or may not take that into account). The PDVSA bond interest due in late February ($600 million) does not have a grace period and would be instant default. A default on one does not accelerate the other. The chance that they strategically default on one and not the other and the grace period causes this to be scored a no is why I’m at 24% instead of 36%.

Venezuela has one of the worst managed economy in the whole world. CDS's are trading at levels that suggest a default (79% in the next 12 months and 20% in the next 5 years). However, although default looks almost like a certainty, it´s important to raise some considerations here. Nicolás Maduro's Government does not want to default on its debt, because eviction is something that could follow right after that. So, self-preservation has a heavy weight here. Thus, what I believe that is going to happen is that Venezuela will continue to swap part of its gold reserves (US$ 16.4 billion) to meet its debt obligation at the same time that will force import contraction. It´s important to notice that Maduro is trying to pass an economic emergency decree in Congress, which was refused, so far, by opposition. Finally, China, Russia and now Iran (thanks to the end of the economic embargo) could bail out Venezuela with another loan. Thus, in a nutshell I believe that there is a 83% of probability of a Venezuelan default this year. However, a default before 1 March 2016 has, in my opinion a lower chance of 14%.

Regarding my question about grace period payments, I received an answer from the GJ team last night:
"Thank you again for your question. The question team discussed but decided not to issue official guidance on this specific question, however it raised an important issue for how we set the deadlines for future questions on default and other measures so thank you for raising it.  Please use your best judgement, keeping in mind that, in general, it is GJI's policy not to close questions based on events that occur after the deadline has passed. You can see our general guidance on that issue and others on our Question FAQ (https://www.gjopen.com/faq/questions). Thank you again for raising this issue." That's a shame. Good to know that they may take grace periods into account for future debt default questions. I would recommend that they set the standard as "This question will be judged a yes if by 31 March at least two major ratings agencies or banks judge Venezuela to be in default or technical default on any debt payments due before 1 March 2016." But in this case, oh well. The large $1.5 billion coupon payment in the final week in February has a 30 day grace period. Banks usually provide the country or debtor the 30 days to pay, then announce the country is retroactively in default as of the payment date. The PDVSA interest payment in February (a couple hundred million) has zero grace period. If they default, it is immediate. The consensus analysis from bond market junkies is that the sovereign debt and Pdvsa debt are separate, meaning a default on one will not allow bond holders to accelerate the other. The question of which assets can or will be seized in case of sovereign or Pdvsa default remains up in the air. I write that out because Venezuela may choose to strategically default on one debt and hope to protect the other, while bond holders may try to treat it all as one issue. There are some interesting reasons for Venezuela to choose to default on one and not the other, and which one they default on will determine if they get a grace period. Then again, they could pay all their bills in February as expected (I have a 64% chance of that occurring) and this will all be a moot point. Dropping my forecast by 1/3 from 36 to 24 based on the non-clarification of the grace period issue.

However, the vast majority of that is gold. And most of the gold is stored in Caracas (stupid, stupid, stupid), not London or New York, meaning it can't be easily leveraged for a quick loan or sold for cash. According to this analysis, which appears accurate compared to the country's official 2015 statements, Venezuela only has $1.3 billion in liquid cash. Other analysis suggests that number may be closer to $3 billion.  They must pay a $1.5 billion sovereign coupon in the final week of February, plus another $600 million in interest on other payments, for this question to resolve as a no. Plus, the government has to pay for food and anything else the people in the country want (at a cost of about $1.1 billion per month), and nearly every country on earth is demanding cash on delivery or before delivery, which eats into the reserves.  No problem, right? If they're running low on funds, just have PDVSA transfer over some more funds. Or pull from the mysterious Fondev black box account that nobody knows how much is in. Or borrow more from China. Or the IMF special drawing rights.  Except with the Venezuelan oil barrel only pulling in $20 per barrel, that is their break-even cost. PDVSA is currently losing or barely making any money on each barrel and nobody knows how much they have left. AND Pdvsa needs to pay cash on market for naptha to dilute the country's heavy oil if they want anything to work. Eventually Fondev runs out of money. China may not be in the mood to lend billions (Venezuela actually owes China a few billion in payments this year). COMMENT:  Here, thanks to wikipedia, is what a CCC rating means:  Non-investment grade
BB  : more prone to changes in the economy
B  : financial situation varies noticeably
CCC  : currently vulnerable and dependent on favorable economic conditions to meet its commitments
CC  : highly vulnerable, very speculative bonds
C  : highly vulnerable, perhaps in bankruptcy or in arrears but still continuing to pay out on obligations
D  : has defaulted on obligations and Fitch believes that it will generally default on most or all obligations
NR  : not publicly rated

http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-01/venezuelan-bonds-rally-as-government-said-to-own-25-of-debt October 1, 2015  " . . . Finance Minister Rodolfo Marco Torres was said to have told investors in New York that government entities own about a quarter of the nation’s foreign bonds, spurring optimism that the nation will avoid default in the near-term.
. . .
"Torres told investors Wednesday that the government owns as much as 25 percent of the nation’s total debt stock, without providing details on which bonds it bought, and said officials are weighing liability-management proposals, according to two people with knowledge of the matter who asked not to be identified because the meeting was private. That’s a bigger holding than investors had expected, assuming the bulk is in the shorter-dated debt, and is reducing odds that the government will default over the next three years, according to BancTrust & Co.  “Even if we assume the stock to be distributed along the entire curve, it still gives ground for a rally,” Guillermo Quiroga, an analyst at BancTrust, said in an e-mailed response to questions. “It reduces default probabilities and encourages further buyback expectations.” "The government has about $5 billion in bond payments due in the last three months of this year and about $10 billion due in 2016. In total, Venezuela has about $70 billion in outstanding dollar-denominated debt securities, including bonds issued by state-owned oil company Petroleos de Venezuela SA, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. "Because the total debt stock is sizable, it’s “highly implausible” that the government has bought back as much as a quarter of it, said Francisco Rodriguez, an economist at Bank of America Corp. It’s more likely that government entities own about a quarter of the nation’s short-term bonds, which would amount to about $3.5 billion of bonds due through 2017, Rodriguez said. He estimates that the government owns about 14 percent of the total debt stock.
~~~~~~~

http://blogs.barrons.com/emergingmarketsdaily/2015/09/03/venezuela-default-risk-overstated/ Despite a slump in oil revenue on which Venezuela depends, the indebted country has the resources and willingness to meet its debt obligations without defaulting this year, says a Bank of America/Merrill Lynch Analyst writing from Caracas where he’s been meeting with policymakers, politicos, private-sector players and local economic analysts.  He says the market has been overestimating the chances of a Venezuela default and underestimating the chances of a political transition in 2016 following elections in December. He sides with the bulls, who point to the magnitude of the country’s assets and its access to non-conventional sources of debt financing (China just made another loan to Venezuela.) Rodriguez writes: “The overwhelming consensus among locals is that the government will comply with this year’s amortizations. Authorities assured us that state-owned entities have repurchased the bulk of the P15 amortizations as well as an important part of the P17s, at the same time as PDVSA [Petroleos de Venezuela, the state-owned oil company] continues to set aside the cash to make these amortizations when they come due. The implication is that PDVSA will be able not only to pay this year, but also to provide state-owned entities such as the PDVSA pension fund with the cash necessary to start repurchasing the 2016 amortizations …
In contrast, locals are much more divided on whether a default will occur in 2016 … We continue to see a second-half 2016 default as the less probable scenario …
Venezuelan political figures are beginning to acquaint themselves with the nuances of the distinction between default, restructuring and refinancing. Almost everyone on the opposition side is against the idea of a hostile default or repudiation, though some would be amenable to a friendly restructuring. Many are unaware that in the absence of CACs [collective action clauses] in PDVSA and some sovereign bonds, the legal difficulties posed by a friendly restructuring are similar to those entailed by a hostile default. The discussion is made even more confusing by the fact that many in the opposition would like to see the [President Nicolas] Maduro administration default not because they think this is a good policy choice, but because it would serve as demonstration of its incapacity to manage the economy. This fact is also one of the reasons why the government is willing to pay a very high cost to continue to service its external debt.”
~~~~~~~
